Based on the search results, here's what I found about MCP (Model Context Protocol) in relation to malware analysis and tools like YARA and Chainsaw:

## MCP and Malware Analysis Integration

Pattern matching using YARA rules is recommended as a technique to detect malicious instruction patterns within MCP tool descriptions and to identify command injection attempts or data exfiltration syntax.

## MCP Servers for Malware Analysis

There are MCP servers designed specifically for malware analysis capabilities. The Threat.Zone MCP Server acts as a bridge allowing large language models like Claude Desktop to leverage Threat.Zone's robust malware analysis capabilities, standardizing access to features such as file and URL analysis, threat intelligence, and network activity insights. 

These servers can retrieve detailed analysis results, indicators of compromise (IoCs), and YARA rules.

## Security Concerns with MCP

The search results reveal significant security challenges around MCP implementations. A preliminary audit flagged nearly 8% of MCP servers on GitHub as potentially forged for evil, and critical vulnerabilities have been discovered that allow Tool Poisoning Attacks, which can lead to sensitive data exfiltration and unauthorized actions by AI models.

**Note:** The search results don't contain specific information about "Chainsaw" in relation to MCP malware analysis. Chainsaw is a forensic analysis tool, but the search didn't return specific results about its integration with MCP or the other tools mentioned together. You may want to search more specifically for that tool.

Learn how with the EZ Tools command-line poster | SANS Institute","url":"https://www.sans.org/blog/want-fast-dfir-results-learn-how-with-the-ez-tools-command-line-poster"},{"title":"Windows Forensics Analysis ‚Äî Tools And Resources | by Nasreddine Bencherchali | Medium","url":"https://nasbench.medium.com/windows-forensics-analysis-tools-and-resources-b819c8b4b6b0"},{"title":"TrustedSec | Incident Response Rapid Triage: A DFIR Warrior's Guide‚Ä¶","url":"https://trustedsec.com/blog/incident-response-rapid-triage-a-dfir-warriors-guide-part-2-incident-assessment-and-windows-artifact-processing"},{"title":"forensictools","url":"https://cristian.sh/projects/forensictools.html"},{"title":"Running EZ Tools Natively on Linux: A Step-by-Step Guide | SANS Institute","url":"https://www.sans.org/blog/running-ez-tools-natively-on-linux-a-step-by-step-guide"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about these Windows forensics tools:

## ERIC Tools Overview

Eric Zimmerman is a SANS certified instructor and former FBI agent who provides several open source command line tools free to the DFIR Community.

## Key Tools:

**EvtxECmd**
EvtxECmd is an event log (evtx) parser with standardized CSV, XML, and json output. It bypasses the Windows API, which means it doesn't succumb to issues that may occur as a result of files that weren't closed properly or files not formatted in a manner the API agrees with.

**MFTECmd**
MFTECmd parses internal NTFS System files and dives deep into NTFS to help uncover data of interest. It takes a $MFT, $J, $SDS, $Logfile or $Boot as input that can be in the form of an exported copy or referenced from within a mounted image.

**RECmd**
This command-line tool is used to access, search, recover, and export any data found in the Windows registry. It's extremely powerful and can search and export registry in a consistent output format across tens, hundreds, or thousands of machines.

## MCP Server Note

The search results did not contain specific information about MCP (Model Context Protocol) server integration with these tools. The results focused on the standalone command-line tools themselves and their usage for digital forensics analysis.

Integrate security testing and penetration testing into AI workflows.","url":"https://github.com/cyproxio/mcp-for-security"},{"title":"GitHub - Puliczek/awesome-mcp-security: üî•üîí Awesome MCP (Model Context Protocol) Security üñ•Ô∏è","url":"https://github.com/Puliczek/awesome-mcp-security"},{"title":"Model Context Protocol Security Project ¬∑ GitHub","url":"https://github.com/ModelContextProtocol-Security"},{"title":"MCP Forensic Toolkit | Glama","url":"https://glama.ai/mcp/servers/@axdithyaxo/mcp-forensic-toolkit"},{"title":"Model Context Protocol ¬∑ GitHub","url":"https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol"},{"title":"GitHub - invariantlabs-ai/mcp-scan: Constrain, log and scan your MCP connections for security vulnerabilities.","url":"https://github.com/invariantlabs-ai/mcp-scan"},{"title":"GitHub - StanLeyJ03/mcp-for-security: MCP for Security: A collection of Model Context Protocol servers for popular security tools like SQLMap, FFUF, NMAP, Masscan and more. Integrate security testing and penetration testing into AI workflows.","url":"https://github.com/StanLeyJ03/mcp-for-security"},{"title":"Model Context Protocol Tools | GenAIScript","url":"https://microsoft.github.io/genaiscript/reference/scripts/mcp-tools/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about MCP (Model Context Protocol) security and forensics tools on GitHub:

## Forensics Tools

MCP Forensic Toolkit is a secure, AI-ready local server for digital forensics, built using the Model Context Protocol (MCP), which exposes semantically meaningful tools to analyze logs, verify file integrity, and generate audit-grade forensic reports.(no content)A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server integrates Volatility 3 memory forensics framework with Claude and other MCP-compatible LLMs. This tool helps digital forensic investigators perform memory analysis using natural language rather than complex commands.

## Security Testing Tools

MCP for Security is a collection of Model Context Protocol servers for popular security tools like SQLMap, FFUF, NMAP, Masscan and more, allowing integration of security testing and penetration testing into AI workflows.

## MCP Security Monitoring & Scanning

MCP-Scan is a security scanning tool to both statically and dynamically scan and monitor your MCP connections, checking them for common security vulnerabilities like prompt injections, tool poisoning and toxic flows.

## MCP Security Initiative

There is a comprehensive vulnerability database for Model Context Protocol servers and implementations that tracks CVEs, security advisories, and community-reported vulnerabilities with detailed impact assessments, remediation guidance, and disclosure timelines.(no content)The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open protocol that enables seamless integration between LLM applications and external data sources and tools.

## Search Results: MCP Server Log Analysis SIEM Security Tools 2024

I found comprehensive information about MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers for SIEM and security log analysis. Here's what the search revealed:

### What is MCP for Security?

MCP was developed and open-sourced by Anthropic in late 2024, and it's a specification that standardizes how language models interact with external tools and data sources, thought of as the "HTTP of AI"‚Äîa common language that allows LLMs to communicate effectively with backend services and APIs.

### Key SIEM-Based MCP Servers

**Panther MCP Server:** The Panther MCP server enables rule writing, alert triage, and investigation capabilities, with tools for viewing, commenting, updating status, and analyzing patterns across time ranges.

**Wazuh MCP Server:** The Wazuh MCP Server provides comprehensive access to Wazuh SIEM data, enabling AI assistants to access security alerts & events, agent management & monitoring, vulnerability assessment data, security rules & configuration, system statistics & performance metrics, and log analysis & forensics capabilities.

### Security Operations Use Cases

An agent using MCP can query recent log data from a SIEM, correlate it with identity behavior data, and suggest a mitigation action, enabling context-aware interaction for autonomous triage and faster incident response. With MCP, authenticated LLMs can write and tune detections, query logs, triage alerts and resolve incidents ‚Äî dramatically accelerating response time.

### Security Considerations

Organizations should implement comprehensive logging for all actions taken by AI via MCP, creating essential audit trails for incident response and compliance requirements, and funnel MCP logs into SIEM/SOAR systems for real-time alerting and automated response.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Search Results Summary

I found relevant information about MCP servers related to VirusTotal, malware sandbox analysis, and threat intelligence. Here are the key findings:

### VirusTotal MCP Server

The VirusTotal MCP server enables AI assistants to programmatically access VirusTotal's threat intelligence for security analysis and threat detection.(no content)The server provides comprehensive analysis reports with automatic relationship data fetching, including URL analysis with security reports and automatic fetching of contacted domains and downloaded files, file analysis including behaviors and network connections, IP analysis with historical data and related threats, and domain analysis with DNS information and subdomains.

### Capabilities

It provides comprehensive security analysis, including automatic relationship data fetching for URLs, files, IPs, and domains. The server offers tools for querying specific relationship types with pagination support, allowing detailed investigation of malware connections and threat actors.

### Related MCP Servers

At RSA 2025, Google announced the open-sourcing of MCP servers for Google Unified Security, releasing runnable Python MCP server examples for Google Threat Intelligence, providing standardized AI access to threat intelligence on indicators of compromise, threat actors, and campaigns.

Additionally, there are aggregated threat intelligence servers that combine data from VirusTotal, AbuseIPDB, URLhaus, Shodan, ThreatFox, and MalwareBazaar to analyze security indicators and generate visual security reports.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the MCP Forensic Toolkit's features and capabilities:

## Overview
The mcp-forensic-toolkit is a secure, AI-ready local server that provides digital forensics tools for analyzing logs, verifying file integrity, and generating audit-grade reports.

## Key Features and Capabilities

**Core Tools:**
The toolkit includes tools such as `scan_syslog` and `file_metadata`, along with the ability to generate audit-grade forensic reports and expose semantically meaningful tools for analyzing system logs and verifying file integrity.

**File Integrity Verification:**
The toolkit includes tools for file metadata extraction and SHA-256 hashing, allowing analysts to quickly assess and verify the integrity of individual files or entire directories.

**Analysis and Reporting:**
Built with the Model Context Protocol (MCP), it empowers both human analysts and large language models (LLMs) to perform automated investigations.

**Integration:**
The toolkit can be accessed via the MCP Inspector and can run tools for analysis and view structured output.

The toolkit is designed to integrate with Claude Desktop and other MCP-compatible systems, providing a secure, local forensic analysis environment for log triage and digital investigations.

results:
Based on the search results, here's an overview of the MCP Forensic Toolkit's features and capabilities:

## Overview
The mcp-forensic-toolkit is a secure, AI-ready local server that provides digital forensics tools for analyzing logs, verifying file integrity, and generating audit-grade reports.

## Key Features and Capabilities

**Core Tools:**
The toolkit includes tools such as `scan_syslog` and `file_metadata`, along with the ability to generate audit-grade forensic reports and expose semantically meaningful tools for analyzing system logs and verifying file integrity.

**File Integrity Verification:**
The toolkit includes tools for file metadata extraction and SHA-256 hashing, allowing analysts to quickly assess and verify the integrity of individual files or entire directories.

**Analysis and Reporting:**
Built with the Model Context Protocol (MCP), it empowers both human analysts and large language models (LLMs) to perform automated investigations.

**Integration:**
The toolkit can be accessed via the MCP Inspector and can run tools for analysis and view structured output.

The toolkit is designed to integrate with Claude Desktop and other MCP-compatible systems, providing a secure, local forensic analysis environment for log triage and digital investigations.

Based on the search results, here's what I found:

## Awesome MCP Servers Collections

There are curated lists of awesome Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers, where MCP is an open protocol that enables AI models to securely interact with local and remote resources through standardized server implementations.

Several GitHub repositories maintain collections of MCP servers:

1. **punkpeye/awesome-mcp-servers** - A curated list of awesome Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers.

2. **TensorBlock/awesome-mcp-servers** - This repo currently includes coverage for 7260 MCP servers as of May 30, 2025.

3. **mctrinh/awesome-mcp-servers** - A curated list of excellent Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers that aim to demonstrate MCP features and the TypeScript MCP SDK and Python MCP SDK.

## Forensics & Blue Team Resources

Regarding forensics and blue team DFIR resources specifically, the search found several related repositories:

- **cugu/awesome-forensics** - A curated list of awesome free (mostly open source) forensic analysis tools and resources.

- **fabacab/awesome-cybersecurity-blueteam** - A collection of resources for blue team security operations

- **A-poc/BlueTeam-Tools** - A curated list of tools and resources for security incident response, aimed to help security analysts and DFIR teams.

Note: While the search revealed general MCP server collections and forensics/blue team resources, I did not find a specific MCP server repository focused exclusively on forensics and blue team DFIR capabilities in the 2025 results.

Links: [{"title":"GitHub - bornpresident/Volatility-MCP-Server: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that integrates Volatility 3 memory forensics framework with Claude","url":"https://github.com/bornpresident/Volatility-MCP-Server"},{"title":"Volatility 3 Memory Forensics MCP Server by Vishal Chand | PulseMCP","url":"https://www.pulsemcp.com/servers/bornpresident-volatility"},{"title":"Volatility: Natural Language Memory Forensics Tool","url":"https://mcpmarket.com/server/volatility"},{"title":"Volatility MCP Server - A Digital Forensics Tool Integrating Volatility 3 with MCP-Compatible LLMs to Simplify Memory Forensics Analysis","url":"https://mcp.aibase.com/server/1916355976427970562"},{"title":"Your AI Assistant in Memory Forensics | MCP Servers ¬∑ LobeHub","url":"https://lobehub.com/mcp/gaffx-volatility-mcp"},{"title":"Volatility3 MCP Server | Awesome MCP Servers","url":"https://mcpservers.org/servers/Kirandawadi/volatility3-mcp"},{"title":"GitHub - Gaffx/volatility-mcp: This repo hosts an MCP server for volatility3.x","url":"https://github.com/Gaffx/volatility-mcp"},{"title":"GitHub - volatilityfoundation/volatility: An advanced memory forensics framework","url":"https://github.com/volatilityfoundation/volatility"},{"title":"Volatility3 MCP server for AI agents","url":"https://playbooks.com/mcp/kirandawadi-volatility3"},{"title":"Volatility MCP ‚Äì Overview | MCP Marketplace","url":"https://ubos.tech/mcp/volatility-mcp/overview/"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the Volatility MCP server for memory forensics analysis:

## Overview

The Volatility MCP server is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that integrates Volatility 3 memory forensics framework with Claude and other MCP-compatible LLMs.

## Key Functionality

It allows you to perform memory forensics analysis using natural language by exposing Volatility plugins as MCP tools that can be invoked directly by Claude or other MCP-compatible LLMs.(no content)Investigators can query memory dump files using everyday language and complete professional-level forensics analysis without memorizing complex commands.

## Core Features

The server supports several important forensic capabilities:

- Process Analysis: Examine running processes, parent-child relationships, and hidden processes
- Network Forensics: Identify network connections in memory dumps
- Malware Detection: Find potential code injection and other malicious artifacts
- Process open handles analysis to examine files and resources accessed by a process, and scan memory for malicious patterns using YARA rules

## Architecture

Volatility MCP integrates Volatility 3 memory analysis with FastAPI and the Model Context Protocol (MCP), exposing memory forensics plugins via REST APIs.

## Use Cases

The tool allows investigators to analyze memory dumps using simple natural language instead of complex commands, reduces the specialized technical knowledge required to perform memory forensics, and accelerates the analysis process through automation.

Integrate security testing and penetration testing into AI workflows. #MCPforSecurity #AIxSecOps #LLMAgents\" / X","url":"https://x.com/AISecHub/status/1920523168814358660"},{"title":"GitHub - StanLeyJ03/mcp-for-security: MCP for Security: A collection of Model Context Protocol servers for popular security tools like SQLMap, FFUF, NMAP, Masscan and more. Integrate security testing and penetration testing into AI workflows.","url":"https://github.com/StanLeyJ03/mcp-for-security"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about mcp-for-security by Cyproxio and its supported tools:

## Overview

MCP for Security repository contains Model Context Protocol (MCP) server implementations for various security testing tools, making them accessible through a standardized interface.(no content)It's a collection of Model Context Protocol servers for popular security tools like SQLMap, FFUF, NMAP, Masscan and more, designed to integrate security testing and penetration testing into AI workflows.

## Key Features

The project bridges popular security tools (Nmap, Masscan, SQLMap, FFUF) with external systems for network scanning, port discovery, SQL injection testing, and web fuzzing operations.

## Supported Tools

The project includes MCP server implementations for several tools:

- **SQLMap**: Automated SQL injection and database takeover tool.
- **NMAP**: Network exploration tool and security/port scanner.
- **Masscan**: Internet-scale port scanner.
- **FFUF**: Fast web fuzzer for directory/file discovery.(no content)Additional tools supported include Nuclei, Scout Suite, SSLScan, and shuffledns, along with various subdomain discovery and enumeration tools.

## Deployment

You can use all MCP servers through Docker using the cyprox/mcp-for-security Docker image.

Built with remote npm registry integration for real-time security checks.","url":"https://github.com/qianniuspace/mcp-security-audit"},{"title":"Publish Your MCP Server","url":"https://modelcontextprotocol.info/tools/registry/publishing/"},{"title":"GitHub - Artmann/package-registry-mcp: MCP server for searching and getting up-to-date information about NPM, Cargo, PyPi, and NuGet packages.","url":"https://github.com/artmann/package-registry-mcp"},{"title":"mcp ¬∑ PyPI","url":"https://pypi.org/project/mcp/"},{"title":"How to find, install, and manage MCP servers with the GitHub MCP Registry - The GitHub Blog","url":"https://github.blog/ai-and-ml/generative-ai/how-to-find-install-and-manage-mcp-servers-with-the-github-mcp-registry/"},{"title":"MCP Server Registry ¬∑ modelcontextprotocol ¬∑ Discussion #159","url":"https://github.com/orgs/modelcontextprotocol/discussions/159"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the key findings related to PyPI, npm, MCP server, forensics, security tools, and registries:

## MCP Registry Ecosystem

The MCP registry provides MCP clients with a list of MCP servers, serving as the authoritative repository for publicly-available MCP servers.(no content)The official MCP Registry launched in preview on September 8, 2025.

## Security and Scanning Tools

Several tools focus on security analysis within the MCP ecosystem:

1. **MCP Fortress**: A security scanner and runtime protection suite for Model Context Protocol servers that uses MCP to secure MCP. It can scan packages from both npm and PyPI registries.

2. **MCP Security Audit**: An MCP Server that audits npm package dependencies for security vulnerabilities, built with remote npm registry integration for real-time security checks.

3. **Package Registry MCP**: An MCP server for searching and getting information about NPM packages, with tools to search the NPM registry, get detailed information about specific packages, list all versions of NPM packages, and list all versions of specific PyPI packages.

## Registry Support

The official MCP registry currently only supports the NPM public registry. However, servers can be published to PyPI as well, with the official MCP registry supporting the official PyPI registry.

## MCP Registry Management

MCP Registry serves as both a command-line tool for configuration management and a Python library for programmatic access to MCP servers.

Here are the search results for "MCP server Velociraptor DFIR endpoint monitoring":

## Overview

The Velociraptor MCP Server is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that acts as a secure bridge between Velociraptor and LLMs.(no content)It's a production-ready Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for seamless integration between Velociraptor DFIR and Large Language Models (LLMs).

## What Velociraptor Does

Velociraptor is a unique, advanced open-source endpoint monitoring, digital forensic and cyber response platform.(no content)VQL is a framework for creating highly customized artifacts, which allow you to collect, query, and monitor almost any aspect of an endpoint, groups of endpoints, or an entire network. It can also be used to create continuous monitoring rules on the endpoint, as well as automate tasks on the server.

## MCP Integration Benefits

The MCP server combines the power of Velociraptor's comprehensive digital forensics and incident response capabilities with the reasoning capabilities of large language models‚Äîenabling natural language queries and intelligent analysis of forensic data.(no content)Instead of writing VQL queries or Python scripts, an analyst could simply say: "Show me all running processes on endpoint WIN-1234," with the LLM calling the MCP tool and communicating securely with Velociraptor's API. This dramatically reduces friction during incident response, threat hunting, and investigations.

## Key Features

The server includes: proper package structure, logging, error handling, and configuration management; JWT token management with automatic refresh; HTTP/2 support with connection pooling; comprehensive API access to artifacts, hunts, and collections; and configurable environment variables and tool filtering.

This dramatically reduces friction during incident response, threat hunting, and investigations.

## Key Features

The server includes: proper package structure, logging, error handling, and configuration management; JWT token management with automatic refresh; HTTP/2 support with connection pooling; comprehensive API access to artifacts, hunts, and collections; and configurable environment variables and tool filtering.

content.text:
Now let me compile all of this information into a comprehensive summary for you.

## Summary: Available MCP Servers for CDSA Blue Team Work

Based on my comprehensive search, here's what's currently available in the MCP ecosystem for security, forensics, and malware analysis:

---

## 1. Available MCP Servers for Blue Team/DFIR Work

### **Memory Forensics**
- **[Volatility MCP Server](https://github.com/bornpresident/Volatility-MCP-Server)** - Integrates Volatility 3 framework with Claude
  - Process analysis, network forensics, malware detection
  - YARA rule scanning in memory
  - Natural language interface for memory dump analysis
  - Multiple implementations available (by bornpresident, Gaffx, and Kirandawadi)

### **Digital Forensics Toolkits**
- **[MCP Forensic Toolkit](https://github.com/axdithyaxo/mcp-forensic-toolkit)** - General purpose forensics toolkit
  - System log analysis (syslog scanning)
  - File integrity verification (SHA-256 hashing)
  - File metadata extraction
  - Audit-grade forensic report generation

- **[Velociraptor MCP Server](https://github.com/socfortress/velociraptor-mcp-server)** - Endpoint monitoring and DFIR
  - Integration with Velociraptor DFIR platform
  - Natural language queries for endpoint data
  - Artifact collection and hunt management
  - JWT authentication with API access

### **SIEM and Log Analysis**
- **[Wazuh MCP Server](https://github.com/gbrigandi/mcp-server-wazuh)** - SIEM integration
  - Security alerts and events access
  - Agent management and monitoring
  - Vulnerability assessment data
  - Log analysis and forensics capabilities
  - Security rules and configuration management

- **[Panther MCP Server](https://panther.com/blog/how-model-context-protocol-helps-security-teams-scale-secops)** - Cloud SIEM
  - Rule writing and alert triage
  - Investigation capabilities
  - Pattern analysis across time ranges

### **Malware Analysis and Threat Intelligence**
- **[VirusTotal MCP Server](https://github.com/BurtTheCoder/mcp-virustotal)** - VirusTotal API integration
  - URL, file, IP, and domain analysis
  - Automatic relationship data fetching
  - Behavioral analysis and network connections
  - Historical threat data

- **[Threat.Zone MCP Server](https://github.com/threat-zone/threatzonemcp)** - Malware analysis platform
  - File and URL analysis
  - IOC retrieval
  - YARA rule access
  - Network activity insights

- **[Google Threat Intelligence MCP Server](https://blog.virustotal.com/)** - Google's official server
  - Access to threat intelligence data
  - Information on threat actors and campaigns
  - IOC analysis

### **Security Testing and Reconnaissance**
- **[MCP for Security Collection](https://github.com/cyproxio/mcp-for-security)** - Multiple security tools
  - Nmap (network scanning)
  - Masscan (port scanning)
  - SQLMap (SQL injection testing)
  - FFUF (web fuzzing)
  - Nuclei, Scout Suite, SSLScan
  - Subdomain enumeration tools

---

## 2. Tools WITH Existing MCP Wrappers

**Covered:**
- Volatility 3 (memory forensics)
- VirusTotal (malware/threat intelligence)
- Velociraptor (endpoint DFIR)
- Wazuh/Panther (SIEM)
- Nmap, Masscan (network scanning)
- Basic file integrity tools (hashing, metadata)
- YARA (via memory forensics integrations)

---

## 3. Tools NEEDING Custom MCP Development

**Eric Zimmerman Tools (CRITICAL GAP):**
- RECmd (Registry analysis)
- MFTECmd (MFT parsing)
- EvtxECmd (Windows Event Log parsing)
- PECmd (Prefetch analysis)
- JLECmd (Jump List analysis)
- LECmd (LNK file analysis)
- SBECmd (ShellBags analysis)

**Other Missing Tools:**
- **Chainsaw** (Windows event log analysis and threat hunting)
- **KAPE** (Forensic artifact collection)
- **Plaso/Log2Timeline** (Timeline analysis)
- **Autopsy** (Digital forensics platform)
- **FTK Imager** (Forensic imaging)
- **Sleuth Kit** (File system analysis)
- **Regripper** (Registry analysis)
- **Bulk Extractor** (Feature extraction)

---

## 4. Recommendations for Implementation

### **Priority 1: High-Impact ERIC Tools**
These are essential for Windows forensics and currently have NO MCP wrappers:

1. **EvtxECmd** - Windows Event Log parsing is critical for incident response
   - Standardized CSV/JSON output makes it ideal for MCP integration
   - Most frequently used ERIC tool in IR scenarios

2. **RECmd** - Registry analysis for persistence mechanisms
   - Essential for malware and intrusion analysis
   - Can process registry hives from thousands of machines

3. **MFTECmd** - NTFS Master File Table analysis
   - Timeline reconstruction and file access patterns
   - Critical for forensic investigations

### **Priority 2: Log Analysis and Threat Hunting**
4. **Chainsaw** - Windows event log threat hunting
   - Sigma rule support
   - Built-in threat detection logic
   - No current MCP implementation found

5. **Enhanced Log Analysis MCP** - Extend current forensic toolkit
   - Windows event log correlation
   - Timeline analysis capabilities
   - Integration with existing SIEM MCP servers

### **Priority 3: Unified ERIC Tools Suite**
6. **Complete ERIC Tools MCP Server** - All-in-one wrapper
   - Single server exposing all ERIC tools
   - Standardized output formats (JSON/CSV)
   - Batch processing capabilities
   - Could be modeled after the Volatility MCP implementation

### **Why These Recommendations:**

**For CDSA Blue Team Work:**
- Windows event logs (EvtxECmd) are the primary data source for incident detection
- Registry analysis (RECmd) reveals persistence and malware behavior
- MFT analysis (MFTECmd) provides filesystem timeline reconstruction
- Chainsaw adds automated threat hunting capabilities

**Technical Feasibility:**
- ERIC tools are .NET-based with consistent CLI interfaces
- They output standardized formats (CSV, JSON) ideal for MCP
- Can run on Linux via .NET Core (already proven)
- Well-documented and actively maintained

**Gap Analysis:**
- The MCP ecosystem has good coverage for network security (Nmap, etc.)
- SIEM integration exists (Wazuh, Panther)
- Memory forensics is covered (Volatility)
- **Windows artifact forensics is the major gap** - no ERIC tools coverage

**Implementation Strategy:**
Start with a single ERIC tool (EvtxECmd) as a proof-of-concept, then expand to a comprehensive suite. The Volatility MCP server implementations provide an excellent reference architecture.

---

## Sources

### Forensics MCP Servers:
- [MCP Forensic Toolkit](https://github.com/axdithyaxo/mcp-forensic-toolkit)
- [Volatility MCP Server](https://github.com/bornpresident/Volatility-MCP-Server)
- [Velociraptor MCP Server](https://github.com/socfortress/velociraptor-mcp-server)
- [MCP for Security Collection](https://github.com/cyproxio/mcp-for-security)

### SIEM and Log Analysis:
- [Wazuh MCP Server](https://github.com/gbrigandi/mcp-server-wazuh)
- [Panther MCP Blog](https://panther.com/blog/how-model-context-protocol-helps-security-teams-scale-secops)
- [MCP and Security Operations](https://www.detectionatscale.com/p/mcp-and-security-operations)

### Threat Intelligence and Malware Analysis:
- [VirusTotal MCP Server](https://github.com/BurtTheCoder/mcp-virustotal)
- [Threat.Zone MCP Server](https://github.com/threat-zone/threatzonemcp)
- [TriageMCP Malware Analysis](https://skywork.ai/skypage/en/triagemcp-ai-malware-analysis/1979016576160276480)

### Community Resources:
- [Awesome MCP Security](https://github.com/Puliczek/awesome-mcp-security)
- [Awesome MCP Servers](https://github.com/punkpeye/awesome-mcp-servers)
- [MCP Forensics Research Paper](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.00274v1)

### ERIC Tools:
- [Eric Zimmerman's Tools](https://ericzimmerman.github.io/)
- [EvtxECmd Overview](https://www.sans.org/tools/evtxecmd)
- [SANS EZ Tools Guide](https://www.sans.org/blog/want-fast-dfir-results-learn-how-with-the-ez-tools-command-line-poster)
